data.text:
A book where everything is backwards, where everything stirs away from reality and does not make a whole lot of sense when it comes to relativity. The main character Arthur Dent is being targeted by these unprepossessing aliens to demolish his house to make a intergalactic bypass, when moments later they are going to destroy the earth. All Arthur can worry about is his house when the earth is going to end. In reality a normal human would be worried about surviving. A smart computer built by Deep thought detects that the answer to the ultimate question is Forty-Two, now all of the humans are insanely muddled as to why the answer is Forty-Two. Mice are now ruling over humans when we have experimented with them for years, the mice are the rulers over the humans and are experimenting on them. Satire is used in many ways throughout this book, but there are only a few that really express how today's society is ruled over. Number one satire in the Hitchhiker's guide to the Galaxy is the demolition of Arthur Dent’s house to make an intergalactic bypass. When moments after the earth is destroyed for the same reason. A smart computer built by Deep thought reveals the answer is Forty- Two. Although the humans were unsure of the wild answer, Deep thought was certain that Forty- Two was the correct answer. Only to understand the humans were not exactly sure on what they were asking. This program had been designed to run for ten million years, and it just so happens that the vogons destroy earth five minutes before the program finishes. Satire is present in this situation because the answer to a theoretical question is distorted to cause humor in waiting millions of years just to find out all they were living for was a meaningless answer.
